Philosophy

A note from Dolores

I dispatched fire trucks for thirty-one years in Cedar Falls. Every call was someone's story going wrong at the end. House fires mostly. Sometimes the barbecue. Twice, a hot tub.

In 2018, I dispatched Engine 7 to a structure fire on Elm. The homeowner, Gerald Moss, age 74, died in the upstairs bedroom. At his funeral, forty-three people said the most beautiful things. Gerald heard none of it.

I quit the next morning. Refinanced my duplex. Rented a church basement. Bolted the furniture to the ceiling.

The rhyming started after the casket fell on my head in March 2019. Concussion #3 — the poetic one

A doctor said it might be a minor form of acquired savant syndrome. I said it felt more like a calling that hurt. Either way, every sentence wants a partner now.

✦
The Space

Everything is
upside down

The pews are bolted to the ceiling. You sit in chairs that hang. The organ plays from below the floor through a grate we installed wrong but kept because it sounds like God whispering.

The casket is open and suspended above you. You look up into it. It is very unsettling. That is the point.

My sister said I always load the dishwasher wrong.
My son said I once drove forty miles for his lost shoe.
I didn't know that's what love looks like. Now I do. — Margaret Yoon, alive, age 61
Voices of the living

Attended his own funeral, Feb 2023. Still alive. Called his wife on the drive home.

Common questions

You're wondering

Do I have to be dying to book a session?
No. We've served guests aged 19 to 94. You only need to be alive. That's the one requirement. We check at the door. If you're not alive, we refer you to a traditional parlor down the street. They do not rhyme. They do not invert. We do not judge them for this.
Why is everything upside down?
Because death inverts your life. Everyone you've known suddenly speaks of you in past tense. Your favorite chair is just a chair. We invert the room so your body knows what your mind already suspects: nothing stays the right way up. Also, I got the church basement for half price because of a structural issue and this was the only way to make the ceiling work.
Why does everything on this website rhyme?
In March of twenty-nineteen, a display casket (mahogany, full-size, retail $4,200) detached from the ceiling and struck my head. Since then, my thoughts arrive in couplets. My neurologist, Dr. Ellen Farb, says it's "not dangerous, just unusual." I say a verse is just a hearse that carries words instead of bones. She says to stop proving her point.
What if nobody says anything nice?
It has happened once. The guest's name was Philip. His family sat in silence for eleven minutes. Then his nephew said, "You taught me how to parallel park." Philip wept. The nephew wept. I wept. The tissue box holder, which was also inverted, dispensed tissues onto the floor. We all reached down. It was the most human moment I've witnessed in this basement.
